issues.description: Endpoint path naming is inconsistent between the problem statement (which specifies /persons for all Person endpoints) and the solution implementation (which exposes Person endpoints under /people). This cross-artifact mismatch will confuse students about which path to implement and will cause client/server calls to fail if they follow the problem statement but look at the solution for guidance.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the endpoint paths consistent. Preferably change the server mappings in PersonResource to use the paths described in the problem statement (i.e., @GetMapping("persons"), @PostMapping("persons"), @PutMapping("persons/{personId}"), @DeleteMapping("persons/{personId}")). Alternatively, update the problem statement to use /people consistently— but ensure both client and server use the same path naming.

issues.description: In the solution repository the client and server disagree on a Person endpoint path: PersonController.addPerson and updatePerson use the "people" path, while PersonController.deletePerson uses the "persons" path. At the same time the server exposes "people" endpoints. This internal inconsistency in the reference code will break delete operations and confuse students using the solution as a reference.
issues.suggested_fix: Ensure the client uses the same base path for all Person operations. Update PersonController.deletePerson to call the same base path used by add/update (i.e., change .uri("persons/" + person.getId()) to .uri("people/" + person.getId()) if the server remains using "people"), or change all client methods to use "persons" if the server is changed to that path. Keep client and server consistent.

issues.description: Problem statement specifies the persons endpoints as /persons (POST /persons, GET /persons, PUT /persons/{personId}, DELETE /persons/{personId>) but the solution server implementation exposes the person endpoints under the path "people" (e.g. @GetMapping("people"), @PostMapping("people"), @PutMapping("people/{personId}"), @DeleteMapping("people/{personId}")). This name mismatch between the problem description and the server implementation creates a mapping barrier: students reading the problem expect to implement /persons while the reference server uses /people, causing confusion and failed client-server interactions if the client or student code follows the problem text.
issues.suggested_fix: Use a single consistent path name for the person endpoints across problem, template and solution. Prefer aligning the server and example client with the problem statement by renaming the server mappings from "people" to "persons" (e.g. @GetMapping("persons"), @PostMapping("persons"), @PutMapping("persons/{personId}"), @DeleteMapping("persons/{personId}")). Alternatively, change the problem statement to consistently use "people" — but choose one and update all artifacts to match.

issues.description: Within the solution repository, the client-side PersonController mixes two different path names for the same conceptual resource: POST and PUT requests use the "people" path (uri("people") and uri("people/" + id)), whereas GET and DELETE requests use the "persons" path (uri("persons") for getAll and uri("persons/" + id) for delete). This internal inconsistency in the client prevents coherent mapping to the server and conflicts with the server's chosen path, causing runtime failures and cognitive load for students trying to follow the reference implementation.
issues.suggested_fix: Pick one canonical endpoint path and apply it consistently in client and server. Given the problem statement expects /persons, update the client to call /persons for POST, PUT, GET and DELETE (replace uri("people") usages with uri("persons")). Also update the server if necessary to match that canonical choice. Ensure the template, client and server examples all use the same path string so students can directly map the exercise description to the code.
